instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3536: What is 820-3536? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.EDP_BKLT_EN: What is EDP_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “EDP_BKLT” which stands for “embedded displayport backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
This board was liquid damaged around the lcd connector area and the bottom side of the board by the lcd connector. I have replaced the lcd connector, lcd cable and the following components.
L8300, <CAPACITOR>C8300</CAPACITOR>/03, <CAPACITOR>C8359</CAPACITOR>, I also replaced a component also in that area(image attached) but I don't know what the component is for because i don't have a boardview for for 4924 so I have to use the one for the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3536</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
There are some other caps/resistors and chips that don't look too good in that area but they are for Thunderbolt so I just left them.

There was no continuity from <CAPACITOR>C8300</CAPACITOR>/03 to the BKLT pin 1 of J8300 so I had to run a wire to connect those lines.
When I plug in the charger and screen I feel the CPU getting warm but even after 30 seconds of it being on I see no image on the screen even with a flashlight shined on it.
I also get 3.3v on Pins 6/7 of the connector. Pin 1 for BKLT gives me 0v
<TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> voltages:
Pin 4: 12.56v
Pin 3: 12.46v
Pins 1/2/5/6: 0.05v

<SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is a steady 3.4v

<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR>/02 have the proper resistance measurements
<RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> has 0v on both sides so I think that may be an issue.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
The circled piece is <CAPACITOR>C7778</CAPACITOR>, not critical...

Did you check external video?
Is there USB activity at least?
J8300 must get voltage at pins 5, 28-30 in the first seconds.
The voltage is maintained only if <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> goes high; which means LCD is correctly recognized.
No backlight before that, of course.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Yes I get video when with hdmi output and screen plugged in. I do get USB activity.

Sorry I forgot to list voltages for pins 5, 28-30 in the earlier post but i took them
J8300 - Pin 5: 3.32v 
Pins 28-30: steady 5.12v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>DP_INT_HPD</SIGNAL> voltage; pin4/<CHIP>U8340</CHIP>.
Confirm 3V there.

Next, check all FL8300-3 coils and all <CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR>-9 caps, if present and good.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Yes I get 3.3v on Pin 4 of <CHIP>U8340</CHIP>.
<CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR> - <CAPACITOR>C8327</CAPACITOR> all get a steady 0.45v on Pin 1 and on Pin 2 it starts around .13v and slowly goes down towards 0.03v.
<CAPACITOR>C8328</CAPACITOR>/29 have 0v on everything except for Pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C8328</CAPACITOR> which has around .04v
FL8300-3 look fine visually and it shows around .13v and slowly goes down towards .04v as well

How should I measure if FL8300-3 is good?
<CAPACITOR>C8320</CAPACITOR>-29 in diode mode all measure 0.324v on Pin 1 and OL on Pin 2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
"How should I measure if FL8300-3 is good?"
Check for continuity between their pins...

Be sure to have good conexions between J8300 and all related components.
Did you try other compatible LCD assembly?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Yes there is continuity on all FL8300-3 pins.
I noticed <CAPACITOR>C7766</CAPACITOR>/7/9,<CAPACITOR>C7717</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7776</CAPACITOR> were corroded and looked dark so I replaced those but still that didn't fix the issue.
All of the J8300 pins have a good connection and there is even continuity from J8300 to the connector on the LCD. I don't have another assembly to be able to test.

When I measure Pins 1/2/5/6 of <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> I keep getting -0.05v. Pin 3 has 12.46v and Pin 4 has 12.56. Do you know why it's not getting the correct voltage?
Does <RESISTOR>R7742</RESISTOR> getting 0v an issue since that is the EN pin for <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
If you miss image and backlight at same time, is not from <CHIP>U7700</CHIP> area.
Post <CHIP>U8330</CHIP> voltages.
I still suppose corrosion issue near LCD connector; maybe on the other side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
<CHIP>U8330</CHIP> 
Pin 1 - 0v
Pin 2 - 0v
Pin 3 - 3.32v
Pin 4 - 0v
Pin 5 - 0v
Pin 6 - 3.32v
Pin 7 - 0v
Pin 8 - 3.32v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
So you miss <SIGNAL>LCD_PSR_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>EDP_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL>; both come out from PCH.
PCH recognizes LCD, because <SIGNAL>EDP_PANEL_PWR</SIGNAL> is kept high.
For some reason doesn't enables the other signals.
I suppose communication problem between LCD connector and PCH; corroded traces, or components.
Could also be bad LCD; you must confirm testing another assembly.

If liquid spill affected area from pin1 to pins 3, or 4, that could damaged LCD.
If affected pins 6, or 7, could damaged SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Okay I ultrasonic'd the board again, replaced the lcd cable and connector again and now I see an image on the screen but no backlight.
Now on <TRANSISTOR>Q7700</TRANSISTOR> I get 8.6v on Pin 3 and 12.56v on pins 1/2/5/6.

On pin 1 of J8300 I get around 0.78v and it slowly keeps going down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
<DIODE>D7710</DIODE> is open, or you have broken trace from it to J8300.
Post volatges for <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>; it could also be a problem between Q770 and <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>, maybe L7710...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message: Pin 1 of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> is 12.55v and Pin 2 gets around 52v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
So broken trace to J8300.
Backlight circuit works now; you get 52V because of open circuit...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no video or backlight
threads.message:
Okay I ran some wires and its working fine now. 

Thanks!
